discussion.content: I think the answer is D, cause it can be a Hardware issue and it is the safest choice to make and the next step would be to quarantine the system, since it will affect productivity.

comments.content: Question states he suspects it's a worm. It is also less likely that several users' computers would be experiencing the same hardware issue.

discussion.content: What is there to quarantine, all the PCs in the office are infected?

comments.content: The question states "several users," not all users.

discussion.content: IMAGINE THAT, new hardware brought manufactured with worms installed. What has the world come to.

comments.content: Wouldn't be the first time. It happens in the real world.
He suspects it's a worm so the best thing to do is quarantine.

discussion.content: Don't make sense , if it's hardware issue only i can go with drivers and if its worm issue i can go with quarantine but both , can't be quarantine .

questions.question_text: Several users at an office have noticed their computers have been behaving erratically over the past hour. A technician suspects there may be a network worm or a hardware failure because all the affected computers were purchased together. Which of the following should the technician perform FIRST?
Which of the following forms of regulated data is MOST important to consider when browsing e-commerce sites on the Internet?

discussion.content: Since the question mentions ecommerce and commerce involves money and unless your counterfeiting sending images of money then a credit is used. So I infer PCI as well

Answer should be C. 
PCI Payment Card Industry: Data security Standard and a standard for protecting credit cards. Visiting e-commerce site you will using payment methods and as a user make sure those websites are PCI compliant

comments.content: I also think PCI is the correct answer.

The ONLY reason I think PCI is not the answer is that comptia tries so weirdly hard to to be tricky and uses the word "browsing" instead of "purchasing" as if the person is just window shopping and not actually providing card info.. Assuming the answer is PII, this could refer to plugging in your info to join a rewards program or enter a contest.

discussion.content: Why isn't the answer GDPR? This and PHI are the only regulated areas and PHI doesn't pertain to e-commerce.

Selected Answer: C
Even though it says browsing, PCI is still the most correct answer. You are far more likely in this situation to input CC data (even if you don't end up buying things) while browsing e-commerce sites than you are to supply an SSN, DOB, or other private info (apart from your name).

Selected Answer: B
Personally identifiable information (PII) is a big umbrella for any data that can lead back to a specific individual.
I agree with B, because it says "browsing"

comments.content: The selection of words is what is most important. Learning the small tricks by going over questions will give you a feel for future question on the exam and all other exams.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
READ READ READ, it literally says browsing and not paying or something...... bruhh

However, since May 2018, there has been a new EU regulation in place, which also affects the US market, to an extent. The General Data Protection Regulation applies to all countries in the EU, but more specifically, to the web users within the EU. This means that your US website, if visited by an internet user based in the EU, has to comply with these data protection regulations too. Because of this, it is important that while you make sure you’re up to speed with the local regulations (different states may have different regulations), you should also keep the EU regulations in mind, and put the right measures in place in case you get a visitor from an EU country.
I think it is GDPR, as all the ecommerce websites has to comply the rules of EU.

The key here is that PII is vulnerable to theft while BROWSING not Payment info as browsing only will not effect payments which are related to PCI. They did not mention payment and we cannot presume just because it is a eCommerce website that it is automatically a PCI issue. So PII makes sense.
I don't think it's PCI as they mention as they don't mention taking payments and just to browse.

I gotta say this question threw me under the bus a little bit. I would both agree that it is PII and PCI. But the huge BUT is that the question ask "which of the FOLLOWING forms of regulated data". Meaning that the question implys all of them are regulated. If that is the case then I would go with PCI. If it says otherwise then id choose PII since its actually fully regulated unlike PCI.

comments.content: Agreed. PCI are standards, not regulated data. When browsing the Internet, it is your Personal Identifying Information (PII) that should be of most concern, not typically your Personal Health Information as that would not be a typical browsing session.
Great point with the browsing! I wonder if tracking cookies are consider PII

discussion.content:
I don't think that PCI is not regulated data.
PII, PHI is (federally) regulated data.

questions.question_text: A technician determines a newly installed service is keeping a device from functioning in Windows. Which of the following tools should the technician use to keep the service from being loaded on the PC reboot?

It is used to configure how a computer starts and what programs and services load when Windows starts. Users running Windows 98 or later versions can open msconfig by following the steps below.

The answer is you press the believe button.

Shift + Right-click اجابه موفقه

comments.content: Shift + Right-click works, I tried it on Windows 10 Enterprise

questions.question_text: Which of the following key and mouse combinations can be used to run an application as a different user?

discussion.content:
Whaling is the most correct answer. Normally this is simply phishing, but whaling specifically goes after high-value targets like a CEO of a company.
Spear phishing is close, but not as correct as whaling. Spear phishing is often highly personalized depending on the victim. While it may be argued here that this is specially targeted at this user, because it's a CEO, whaling remains the correct answer.
Impersonation is not as correct; while the email is masquerading as a bank, their main goal is to compromise the CEO's security.
Dumpster diving is incorrect; no indication of document extraction from the trash is given.

comments.content: Whaling is a specific sub-section of spear phishing.

discussion.content: Whaling is the most correct indeed, but it is not in the exam objectives. ...

comments.content: Yeah not sure why this question is in A+. It is a Security+ topic and is in there too.

It states the company's account has several suspicious transactions and instructs the CEO to log in immediately to validate the transactions; otherwise, the account will be frozen. Which of the following BEST describes this email?
